resources.string: The Game of Life is a cellular automaton devised by the mathematician John Horton Conway in 1970. It is a zero-player game, which means its evolution is determined solely by its initial state.
The game is played on a two-dimensional grid made up of living or dead cells. Each cell interacts with its eight surrounding neighbours based on the following rules:
1. Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies through underpopulation.
2. Any live cell with more than three live neighbours also dies through overcrowding.
3. Any live cell with two or three neighbours lives on.
4. Any dead cell with three neighbours will come to life.

To get started, go back and press \'Random Cells\' to create a new grid with 15% of the cells alive, and tap the screen to move forward one generation. Double tap the screen to start or stop continuously creating new generations, or pinch zoom in or out to create more or less cells.
Alternatively, go back and press \'Choose a Layout\' to pick from some of the interesting patterns that have already been discovered.

The last two patterns demonstrate alternative rules, where the \'Replicator\' pattern has new cells born with six neighbours as well as three. The \'Sierpinski\' pattern has new cells born with one neighbour only, and lives on with one or two neighbours only.
